reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s realism/anti-realism-based argument against WAM-convergence (section 2.4), which is an important support for the essay’s overall pessimism about widespread convergence, but not the whole case (the essay also leans on motivational issues, divergence under reflection, power concentration/blockers, and later trade/threat dynamics). So centrality is moderate. The critique has limited refutational force because the essay explicitly notes it is using “realism vs antirealism” as a simplifying frame and even gestures at rephrasing the issue in terms of convergence predictions; it also already considers more sophisticated subjectivist/idealization routes (which overlap with some ‘middle’ views like response-dependence/ideal observer). Still, it is somewhat right that positions like constructivism/contractualism could be treated more explicitly and may allow more convergence than the essay’s stark presentation suggests, so it weakens the framing a bit rather than overturning the argument. The point is mostly correct and clearly stated, with little to no dead weight, and it focuses on a single issue.
title: The realism/anti-realism dichotomy ignores middle positions that could predict convergence
